Planning - Complete plans are a must to help guide people and resources in the event of an emergency.  The Aberdeen Plant has Emergency Action Plans (EAP) in place to handle on-site and off-site incidents.  Our plans have been developed in coordination with the Local Emergency Planning Commission.

Alliances - To provide for additional resources in the event of a major incident, the Aberdeen Plant has agreements with the Aberdeen Fire Department and local emergency medical responders to provide additional resources if required.  These potential responders are given tours of the plant and are familiarized with processes at the plant in the event they are called on to provide assistance.

ACCIDENT HISTORY
The first incident in the plant's history to require reporting under the EPA's Risk Management Plan occurred in December of 2007.  Many changes, both operational and procedural, have been made since, in an attempt to decrease the likelihood of events such as this occurring.

The Aberdeen Plant is proud of the fact that we have never experienced any release resulting in damage to our neighbors.  With our safety systems and employees working every hour, every day, to prevent chemical accidents, we are confident of extending this record of safe operation.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE
The Aberdeen Plant strives to be able to respond to any situation.  To accomplish this goal, our emergency preparedness efforts focus on four areas:

Personnel - The most important part of any response plan is well-trained, qualified people such as Aberdeen's Emergency Response Team (ERT).  The team consists of employees from various departments within the plant.  They train annually at places such as the Mississippi State Fire Academy.  On-site training is conducted regularly to test and refine the skills acquired at those facilities.  The ERT members have specialized training in firefighting, hazardous materials handling, confined space rescue and medical training.

Resources - The proper equipment is a necessary requirement for any job.  In the field of emergency response, it is necessary that equipment, materials, and labor be available immediately as needed.  The Aberdeen Plant is equipped with such items as chemical transportation response equipment, automatically activated fire water systems, portable fire water monitors, firefighting gear, fire extinguishers and other necessary equipment.

The Westlake Aberdeen PVC Plant has a long history of safe operation in the Aberdeen community.  Our employees work hard every hour, every day to provide a safe workplace for themselves while protecting the environment inside and outside our fences.      

PLANT INFORMATION
The Aberdeen Plant produces polyvinyl chlorine (PVC or vinyl) resins and compounds.  These materials are used in downstream operations to produce wire and cable insulation, vinyl siding, pipe, packaging, and numerous other similar products.  The resins and compounds are produced by the polymerization of vinyl chloride monomer (VCM).  After the polymerization, the resin is dried and stored for shipping.  Most of the VCM used in the process is shipped by rail from the company's Louisiana operations.  The VCM is a gas at normal conditions but is kept under pressure and handled as a liquid, in a similar manner to propane.  At certain concentrations VCM is flammable, therefore the plant has many safety systems in place.  Both the Flammable Chemical Vinyl Chlorine Monomer and the Toxic Chemical Chlorine, which is used as a water treatment additive, have been addressed in the RMP preparation.

WORST-CASE SCENARIO FLAMMABLE
In calculating the worst-case scenario for flammable chemicals, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), requires the following assumptions be made:
1) Catastrophic (complete) failure of the largest storage vessel
2) Complete loss of the contents of the vessel and vaporization of the liquid in ten minutes
3) Mixing of sufficient air with the vapors to generate an explosion with a 10 percent yield-the worst seen for mixture of flammable vapors with air
4) None of the plant's procedures or emergency systems work
5) Ignition of the vapor cloud as soon as all the material vaporizes
